The cause accomplish'd after many a rubb,</br>And many a term elaps'd, with serious brow</br>Old Nichil sits him down, and o'er his desk</br>Transaction past revolves, contriving how</br>His Bill of Costs to frame.  He twirls his wig,</br>He strokes his chin, and to his nose applies</br>"The pungent grains of titillating dust."</br>Much he exerts his cogitative pow'rs,</br>Studious how best to cook the matter up,</br>And, after all deductions, how to make</br>The ballance in his favour.  "Labor hic,</br>Hoc opus."  O'er his may-bundled notes,</br>And memorandums private, oft he turns</br>Then minutes each occurrence.  Ev'ry act</br>And trivial circumstance recorded stands.</br>The long, long declaration, on whose base</br>All actions are erected, life o' th' cause,</br>And origin of matter, swells the charge.</br>To this succeeds a fee to council paid</br>Of one pound one, to methodize the draught.</br>Good harmless man!  he strives not to abridge</br>Prolixity — but, like an honest dealer,</br>Gives amplest measure — lengthens ev'ry count,</br>And puzzles special pleader.  Without hand</br>Of council sage, attorney!  what art thou!</br>What, but an animal, that fear'st to tread</br>The boggy heath of law without a guide.</br>What art thou with him?  tell to me I pray;</br>What, but a great man-child in leading-strings!</br>What, but a hobby-horse, on whose jaded back</br>The jocky rides, and spurs thee to the goal.

Now after many an intervening fee</br>The closing grand one comes, and tho' the last,</br>Not least inferior.  Term-fee it is call'd.</br>Oh!  pleasing sound!  and yet more pleasing still</br>The silver profits that accrue from thee,</br>Thou total sum of lucre without loss!</br>Right sage the wight, who tack'd thee to his bill,</br>And privileg'd thee first.  Howe'er the don,</br>Prothonotary height, or Master, dare</br>With plumed instrument each clause to prune,</br>And lop whole fees away, he durst not touch</br>This monument of value — for the love</br>He bears his office, and authority,</br>He durst not — 'tis the due of ev'ry term,</br>A tax on clients, and th' attorney's charter.</br>At length 'tis finish'd.  On poor client's eye</br>It swells astonishing.  Term after term,</br>Vac. after vac. he sees expences rise,</br>And swears in bitterness of heart to find</br>Himself at last the debtor; for he thought,</br>Weak, foolish man!  the balance due to him.</br>But most he frets, and vents his fruitless rage,</br>In anguish o'er the term-fee.  "This, he cries,</br>Stings home — it cuts — it rives my very soul;</br>This heavy charge for doing nought at all;</br>This premium for laziness." — This said,</br>From pocket he extracts his purse, pays down</br>The sum demanded — exit with a frown,</br>And damns attornies for a set of K—.</br>
